subject: Art
title: Manual Mode
description: Taking full control of aperture, shutter speed, and ISO.

hook.text: Auto mode makes decisions for you. Manual mode puts you in charge of every decision: aperture, shutter speed, and ISO. It's harder â€” but it's where you stop taking pictures and start making photographs.

buildup.text: Manual workflow: 1) Set ISO based on available light (100 outside, 800 inside, 3200 dark). 2) Set aperture for desired depth of field. 3) Set shutter speed until the meter reads correct exposure. 4) Shoot. 5) Check histogram. 6) Adjust.

discovery.text: Manual isn't always necessary. Aperture priority (you set aperture, camera sets shutter) handles 80% of situations perfectly. Manual shines when: lighting doesn't change (studio), when auto gets fooled (backlight), or when learning.

twist.text: The real benefit of learning manual: even when you use auto modes, you UNDERSTAND what the camera is doing and can override it intelligently. Manual fluency makes you better in every mode.

climax.text: Spend one day shooting only in manual. It'll be slow at first. By the end of the day, you'll understand the exposure triangle intuitively. That understanding stays with you even when you switch back to auto modes.

punchline.text: Learn manual to understand light. Then use whatever mode gets you the shot.

quiz.question: What is the main benefit of learning manual mode?
options: You deeply understand the exposure triangle, making you better in every mode
